summary: I’m reading ADWD for the first time, and even though I’m only half way through it and there’s no Sansa in this book, I did...
body:
I’m reading ADWD for the first time, and even though I’m only half way through it and there’s no Sansa in this book, I did notice something that could be a hint of parallel to Sansa and Sandor in Dany’s chapter.

The chapter is about Dany considering marriage. Daario has been away from her from a time, and in that time she has fantasies and romanticised him in her head, and thinks about him coming home a lot. 

But, once he returns and she spends time with him, she realises he’s not a good man and it shatters her illusions and romanticism of him. 
—


He had been so long away, Dany had almost forgotten what he was. Sellswords were treacherous by nature, she reminded herself. Fickle, faithless, brutal. He will never be more than he is. He will never be the stuff of kings.

“The pyramids are strong,” she explained to him. “We could take them only at great cost. The moment we attack one the others will rise against us.”

“Then winkle them out of their pyramids on some pretext. A wedding might serve. Why not? Promise your hand to Hizdahr and all the Great Masters will come to see you married. When they gather in the Temple of the Graces, turn us loose upon them.”

Dany was appalled. He is a monster. A gallant monster, but a monster still.

“Do you take me for the Butcher King?”

“Better the butcher than the meat. All kings are butchers. Are queens so different?”

“This queen is.”

Daario shrugged. “Most queens have no purpose but to warm some king’s bed and pop out sons for him. If that’s the sort of queen you mean to be, best marry Hizdahr.”

Her anger flashed. “Have you forgotten who I am?”

“No. Have you?”

Viserys would have his head off for that insolence. “I am the blood of the dragon. Do not presume to teach me lessons.” When Dany stood, the lion pelt slipped from her shoulders and tumbled to the ground. “Leave me.”

—

After which she sends him out on the field again and plans to never see him again after having her illusions shattered.

Thinking about Sansa and her fantasies about the Hound, I couldn’t help but think this might be what would happen if Sansa left with the Hound at the Blackwater. A lot of GRRM’s characters in ADWD are there to show what would realistically happen if this thing you readers want to happen now, happened without the characters having time to change and learn first.
Maybe I’m reading too much into this, but without time for Sandor to repent and change and better himself on the Quiet Isle, I feel like realistically, a Sansan relationship would have turned out this way too and maybe this is GRRM’s way of reminding us.

summary: Libros: Juego de tronos (Canción de hielo y fuego ), George RR Martin Entrada originalmente publicada el 3 de febrero de 2011....
caption:
Libros: Juego de tronos (Canción de hielo y fuego ), George RR Martin

Entrada originalmente publicada el 3 de febrero de 2011.

Desde que leí “El nombre del viento” le he cogido el gustillo a esto de la literatura de fantasía, y como esa recomendación me fue bien, he decidido hacer caso a algunos sabios en la materia y empezar con la serie “Canción de hielo y fuego”.

Juego de tronos es el primer tomo de esta saga (creo que son cinco) y, aunque me esperaba un poco más, me ha encantado. De hecho, creo que voy a volver a ver la serie de Los pilares de la tierra solo por el mono de medievo que se me ha quedado.

Fantasía medieval, pero sin trolls, gnomos (bueno.. gnomo hay uno), magia, gigantes, etc etc. Si que hay alguna criatura fantástica danzando por ahí, pero nada que se salga de lo normal. (Flipé cuando me encontré con zombis, como si tal cosa) De hecho, todo lo fantástico que nos encontramos aquí, está (supuestamente) detrás del muro. Una especie de muralla china de no se cuantos mil años de antigüedad que está al norte del continente. Allí vive la Guardia de la noche, patrullando el muro y pasando mucho frío, y, a veces, miedo por las cosas misteriosas que suceden allí.

La cosa es la siguiente: un mundo ficticio lleno de señores y gente que le mola hacerse llamar rey. Robert Baratheon es el Rey de los siete reinos y Eddard Stark es su mano (el primer ministro, como si dijéramos, imagino que no os habéis pensado que su mano tiene un nombre y tal) aunque muy a su pesar, porque adora su señorío, donde siempre hace frío (que bonito pareado). Pero también hay un continente un poco alejado de la mano de dios por donde pululan los herederos de la corona del rey anterior. Poco más voy a decir sin spoilear a saco, así que lo dejo aquí.

Me habían dicho que era bastante susceptible de engancharme como una loca y tal, la verdad, no ha sido para tanto, sí, me he leído un poco más de 700 páginas en un par de semanas pero es ahora, cuando empiezo el segundo libro, cuando noto el enganche supremo. Es que claro, el primero no tiene un desenlace muy desenlazante, o, por lo menos lo que yo me esperaba. En plan, acabar una historia  (o todas las tramas, vamos) y seguir con otra diferente en el segundo libro, el caso es que la historia tiene una continuación muy clara y es ahora cuando tengo curiosidad por lo que va a pasar a continuación.

Otra curiosidad del libro es la estructura de sus capítulos, en cada uno se centra en un personaje. Me encanta como, si hay varios rondando por el capítulo, se centra realmente en el protagonista y te lo hace notar. Es verdad que hay mil y un personajes, pero no todos son protagonistas (o secundarios fuertes, porque esto es una novela coral, nada de un héroe por encima de los demás y el resto bailándole las aguas), para mí, que no me quedo con los nombres de la mayoría, es un lío padre cuando se juntan los secundarios débiles (los que no tienen tanto peso en la trama, vamos) que no me aclaro con quien es quien, pero bueno, eso es mi déficit de atención.

Poco más que añadir, os la recomiendo muy mucho, sobretodo si os gusta la fantasía no tan infantil. Os mantendré informados sobre el resto de la saga!

summary: Miradas, fanfic de Game of thrones en español.
title: Miradas, fanfic de Game of thrones en español.
description:
Historia: Miradas
Mirla siempre pensó que la vida era solo servir a la muerte, ayudar a su hermana y sobrevivir a su padre hasta que llegó a Poniente y conoció a Jon Snow; un chico de ojos invernales y melancólicos que la llevará a descubrir los peligros del amor.
Jon x OC

summary: You just got thrown into the world of Game of Thrones series. What is the first thing your going to do and who will you side...
question: You just got thrown into the world of Game of Thrones series. What is the first thing your going to do and who will you side with and why?
answer:
I dunno when this got sent but I found it and I’m answering it.

Okay. I’m def hooking up with Dany or Jon. Like. You do NOT want to be on Dany’s bad side that girl stopped giving an eff a long time ago. First thing I do is form a plan to kill Cersei. No point reasoning with her, that bitch is cray. Killing her is the only way to go anymore.

summary:
Might be an unpopular opinion but GoT fans sometimes are so fucking annoying.
Lena posts a picture with Peter and Nikolaj with a...
body:
Might be an unpopular opinion but GoT fans sometimes are so fucking annoying.

Lena posts a picture with Peter and Nikolaj with a message of congratulations for the Emmys and everyone’s like “omg 100% confirmed! TyRioN is A TARgarYEn”.

Or when Maisie posted the picture of her shoes with the hashtag #LastWomanStanding and Lena commented “Queen” and everyone lost their minds.

Gemma Whelan almost got fired because she said she was going to play Asha/Yara and you think they’d write stuff like that?

PEOPLE NEED TO CHILL

summary: [Spoilers] Just Finished Reading Book 1 GoT Thoughts
title: [Spoilers] Just Finished Reading Book 1 GoT Thoughts
body:
I just finished reading the first book. It’s excellent and it’s basically the first season of the show. The main differences I’ve noticed are in the dream sequences which are amazing and the battles that occur at River Run and Whispering Wood. I’m guessing the show simply didn’t have the budget for it but they were really intense fights. But while the overall differences were small, often times small things in this story can be of great importance later on.

A lot of things just beg for answers I don’t have.

The difference in the Night’s Watch vow between the books and show is rather telling. “I am the fire that burns against the cold, the light that brings the dawn, the horn that wakes the sleepers, the shield that guards the realms of men.”

Dany’s memory of a house with a big red door and a lemon tree is also interesting. I heard a theory once that said this is proof that Dany isn’t who she thinks she is. She’s a princess of Dorne. The big red door is something you find in the water gardens and the palace there. Lemons can only be found in part of Westeros: Dorne. I don’t buy it but it’s interesting.

The vision Dany sees of a great wolf and a man wreathed in flame when she’s carried into Khal Drogo’s tent when the witch, Mirri Maz Duur, performs the ritual that kills Dany’s unborn son but saves Drogo’s life stuck in my head the moment I read it. Now the man wreathed in flame, sounds like a depiction of the Lord of Light. I don’t know who or what the wolf refers to.

The absence of Jeor Mormont’s crow in the show now bothers me. “Corn, corn, corn.” “Don’t listen to his lies, I just fed him.” This one will be interesting in future books for sure.

The difference between ravens and crows as it pertains to the Great Other. I’ve heard this theory before and holy shit, there’s something to this one. In the book it talks about the two as brothers but it definitely assigns a strong negative connotation to crows. They seem to tie in with the presence of evil. Even in Bran’s falling dream it’s a three eyed crow, not a raven. And it’s not his friend either. It tries to kill him when Bran succeeds in flying.

Why Hodor didn’t want to go into the Winterfell crypts and what was waiting for Bran down there ties into the idea of the crow as the enemy and even a stand in the for the Great Other. The crypts of Winterfell themselves are much more interesting and potentially ominous in the books.

Cersei’s speculates to Ned that Jon was the son of Ned and Ashara Dayne before delivering the infamous line: “when you play the game of thrones, you win or you die.”

Dany’s promise to Ser Jorah for a valyrian steel sword before she stepped onto Drogo’s funeral pyre.

It’s all fascinating stuff. Anyway, on to book two.



Source: https://ift.tt/2mjRUDY

trail.content:
External image

I just finished reading the first book. It’s excellent and it’s basically the first season of the show. The main differences I’ve noticed are in the dream sequences which are amazing and the battles that occur at River Run and Whispering Wood. I’m guessing the show simply didn’t have the budget for it but they were really intense fights. But while the overall differences were small, often times small things in this story can be of great importance later on.

A lot of things just beg for answers I don’t have.

The difference in the Night’s Watch vow between the books and show is rather telling. “I am the fire that burns against the cold, the light that brings the dawn, the horn that wakes the sleepers, the shield that guards the realms of men.”

Dany’s memory of a house with a big red door and a lemon tree is also interesting. I heard a theory once that said this is proof that Dany isn’t who she thinks she is. She’s a princess of Dorne. The big red door is something you find in the water gardens and the palace there. Lemons can only be found in part of Westeros: Dorne. I don’t buy it but it’s interesting.

The vision Dany sees of a great wolf and a man wreathed in flame when she’s carried into Khal Drogo’s tent when the witch, Mirri Maz Duur, performs the ritual that kills Dany’s unborn son but saves Drogo’s life stuck in my head the moment I read it. Now the man wreathed in flame, sounds like a depiction of the Lord of Light. I don’t know who or what the wolf refers to.

The absence of Jeor Mormont’s crow in the show now bothers me. “Corn, corn, corn.” “Don’t listen to his lies, I just fed him.” This one will be interesting in future books for sure.

The difference between ravens and crows as it pertains to the Great Other. I’ve heard this theory before and holy shit, there’s something to this one. In the book it talks about the two as brothers but it definitely assigns a strong negative connotation to crows. They seem to tie in with the presence of evil. Even in Bran’s falling dream it’s a three eyed crow, not a raven. And it’s not his friend either. It tries to kill him when Bran succeeds in flying.

Why Hodor didn’t want to go into the Winterfell crypts and what was waiting for Bran down there ties into the idea of the crow as the enemy and even a stand in the for the Great Other. The crypts of Winterfell themselves are much more interesting and potentially ominous in the books.

Cersei’s speculates to Ned that Jon was the son of Ned and Ashara Dayne before delivering the infamous line: “when you play the game of thrones, you win or you die.”

Dany’s promise to Ser Jorah for a valyrian steel sword before she stepped onto Drogo’s funeral pyre.

It’s all fascinating stuff. Anyway, on to book two.

body:
I was tagged in this maybe a thousand years ago by @gotarcher94 and @arrows-n-hooks so… Thanks! And let’s do it!

Rules: Name your top ten favorite female characters from different fandoms. Then tag ten people.

1) Daenerys Targaryen (Game of Thrones):

2) Arya Stark (Game of Thrones):

3) Natasha Romanoff aka Black Widow (Marvel Cinematic Universe):

4) Wanda Maximoff aka Scarlet Witch (Marvel Cinematic Universe):

5) Valkyrie (Marvel Cinematic Universe):

6) Éowyn (The Lord of the Rings):

7) Hermione Granger (Harry Potter):

8) Diana Prince aka Wonder Woman (Wonder Woman):

9) Phoebe Buffay (Friends):

10) Katniss Everdeen (The Hunger Games):
